title: Yîs Wùsh Dashây Dàt Sh Kałnìk / The First Wedded Year
author: Seidayaa / Elizabeth Nyman

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Ha wé a káx̱ x̱at x̱ʼeewóosʼ, shóogunáx̱ / wé ax̱ x̱úx̱ du x̱áni yéi x̱at natée— tlél atkʼátskʼu ax̱ jee yéi utí— aag̱áa áwé yú g̱aatáa tlʼátgidáx̱ haandé haa kawduwaḵáa.
sentences.sentence_english: As for what you asked me about, when I was first married to my husband– as yet I had no children– at that time we were told to leave the trapping grounds and come back over this way.

my husband–

at that time we were told to leave the trapping grounds
and come back over this way.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Yóotʼát, at jindaadoogú xátʼaa áwé yéi s aya.óo.
sentences.sentence_english: They had those moose forearm skin sleds.

sentences.sentence_english: He had a rope fastened to [the sled]; “Hold on to this;” he told me, “you'll get tired.” We went a long way.

sentences.sentence_english: The mailman– there were no airplanes then, nor [was there a road passable by car]– it was by dogsled that they brought the mail to Telegraph Creek; they say it's a long way.
